transcript:
Patient: I appreciate you sharing the courtroom analogy and the self-compassion break technique. I can see how these tools can help me challenge my negative thoughts and be kinder to myself. It's going to take practice, but I'm willing to put in the effort.

Therapist: I'm glad you find these techniques helpful, Priya. Remember, practice is key when it comes to reframing thoughts and developing self-compassion. It's normal to face challenges along the way, but with persistence, it will become easier over time.

As we wrap up today's session, let's discuss some homework assignments to help you continue practicing these skills. First, I'd like you to keep using the thought records, focusing on the courtroom analogy when you're struggling to reframe negative thoughts. Aim to complete at least one thought record per day, and bring them to our next session so we can review them together.

Patient: That sounds good. I'll make sure to use the thought records and the courtroom analogy daily.

Therapist: Great! Additionally, I'd like you to practice the self-compassion break technique whenever you notice feelings of worthlessness arising. Take a moment to acknowledge your feelings without judgment, remind yourself that everyone struggles with these feelings at times, and offer yourself some words of kindness and understanding.

Patient: I'll definitely try the self-compassion break technique. It's a good reminder to be kind to myself, even when I'm struggling.

Therapist: Absolutely. Self-compassion is a powerful tool for managing difficult emotions. Lastly, continue practicing the stimulus control technique to improve your sleep. Remember to only use your bed for sleep and intimacy, and if you can't fall asleep within 20-30 minutes, get up and do a calming activity until you feel sleepy.

Patient: I'll keep working on the stimulus control technique. I know it might take some time to see improvements in my sleep, but I'm committed to making these changes.

Therapist: That's a great attitude, Priya. Change takes time, but with consistent effort, you will start to notice improvements in your sleep and overall well-being.

Before we end today's session, I want to check in on your current mood and any final thoughts you'd like to share.

Patient: I'm feeling a bit more hopeful after discussing these new techniques. I know I still have work to do, but I feel like I have some additional tools to help me manage my negative thoughts and feelings of worthlessness. Thank you for your support and guidance.

Therapist: You're welcome, Priya. I'm glad you're feeling more hopeful, and I'm confident that with continued practice, you'll make progress in managing your negative thoughts and improving your overall well-being. Remember, I'm here to support you every step of the way.

Session Summary:
- Main topics discussed:
  - Reviewed thought records and challenges with reframing guilty thoughts related to self-care and setting boundaries
  - Introduced and practiced the courtroom analogy for reframing negative thoughts
  - Discussed additional coping strategies for managing sleep disturbances (stimulus control) and feelings of worthlessness (self-compassion break)
- Techniques or exercises used:
  - Thought records (continued from previous sessions): Priya will continue using thought records, focusing on the courtroom analogy when struggling to reframe negative thoughts. Plan to review thought records in the next session.
  - Reframing techniques (courtroom analogy): Introduced and practiced using the courtroom analogy to objectively examine evidence for and against negative thoughts. Plan to continue practicing this technique when negative thoughts arise.
  - Distress tolerance techniques (deep breathing, grounding, progressive muscle relaxation): Priya has found these techniques helpful in managing overwhelming emotions. Plan to continue practicing these techniques when feeling stressed or overwhelmed.
  - Self-care planning: Priya has been setting aside time for self-care activities and practicing self-compassion when feelings of guilt arise. Plan to continue prioritizing self-care and practicing self-compassion.
  - Behavioral activation: Priya has set goals for attending art classes and practicing Spanish to enhance social connections and improve mood. Plan to continue implementing these goals and track progress using an activity schedule and mood monitoring.
  - Cognitive restructuring: Practiced using thought records and the courtroom analogy to identify and challenge negative thoughts related to self-care, work performance, and worthlessness. Plan to continue using these techniques to support engagement in new activities and social situations.
  - Self-disclosure and active listening: Introduced and practiced through role-play exercises. Plan to continue practicing in real-life interactions, starting with small, positive experiences and building from there.
  - Coping cards: Introduced coping cards as reminders of alternative thoughts and coping statements for managing guilt and anxiety. Plan to create and use coping cards for self-care and social interactions.
  - Role-playing: Practiced role-playing social interactions to build confidence and problem-solve challenges. Plan to continue using role-playing to prepare for real-life social situations.
  - Stimulus control: Introduced stimulus control technique to improve sleep by creating a strong association between bed and sleep. Plan to practice this technique consistently to manage sleep disturbances.
  - Self-compassion break: Introduced self-compassion break technique to manage feelings of worthlessness. Plan to practice this technique whenever feelings of worthlessness arise.
- Homework assigned:
  - Continue keeping thought records, focusing on the courtroom analogy when struggling to reframe negative thoughts. Aim to complete at least one thought record per day and bring them to the next session for review.
  - Practice the self-compassion break technique whenever feelings of worthlessness arise. Acknowledge feelings without judgment, remind yourself that everyone struggles with these feelings at times, and offer yourself words of kindness and understanding.
  - Continue practicing the stimulus control technique to improve sleep. Only use the bed for sleep and intimacy, and if unable to fall asleep within 20-30 minutes, get up and do a calming activity until feeling sleepy.
- Patient's progress, challenges, depression symptoms, and important personal details:
  - Priya is making progress in identifying and challenging negative thoughts related to self-care, work performance, and worthlessness. She is practicing reframing techniques, self-compassion, and prioritizing her own well-being. Depressive symptoms, including sleep disturbances, fatigue, lack of motivation, and feelings of worthlessness, persist but have shown some improvement. Priya's cultural background and religious beliefs are important to her, but she also faces stigma around mental health in her community.
- Core beliefs and intermediate beliefs: Not discussed in this session.
- Important information to carry forward:
  - Priya's thought records, progress with reframing negative thoughts using the courtroom analogy, and experiences with distress tolerance techniques will be reviewed in the next session. Continue to explore the connection between thoughts, feelings, and behaviors, and work on developing additional coping strategies. Monitor progress with behavioral activation goals related to art classes and language learning, as well as self-disclosure and active listening in social interactions.
- Plan for the next session:
  - Review Priya's thought records and discuss any insights or challenges encountered with the courtroom analogy and other reframing techniques.
  - Check in on progress with self-care planning, self-compassion, behavioral activation goals, self-disclosure, and active listening.
  - Continue practicing cognitive restructuring, distress tolerance techniques, and stimulus control for sleep.
  - Discuss any adjustments needed to the treatment plan based on Priya's experiences and progress.
